intro: Cephalanthus occidentalis subsp. salicifolius, commonly known as the willow-leaf sweetshrub, is a shrub native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its lance-shaped, willow-like leaves and clusters of small, fragrant white flowers that bloom in the spring. The plant produces small, dark blue berries that are an important food source for birds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. Its ornamental value and ecological importance make it a notable species in wetland ecosystems.
